Amazingly, it seems to be the only photo with Churchtown in any of our catalogue info! Anywhere else around your old stomping ground that you'd like to see?

comment._content:
That's Great, Thanks very much for uploading this. I live right next to the station and it has changed so so much since then. The signal cabin is still there thankfully! 
Once again thanks for putting this up.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/88162413@N06] Not at all, it's a pleasure! Any info on the station from this time gratefully received...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 23966421@N06
comment._content:
It's amazing how much this place has changed. This looks to have been taken from the Foot Bridge. the two-story house on the left is the old Station Master's house, and as [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley/] points out, it is still standing. The signal cabin is also still standing, though not in use anymore. The new station stands on the empty ground between the old station building and the signal cabin. You can still make out the foundations of the old station building in the carpark - the new fancy bike lockers were built on them a few months ago. The goods sidings in the background are all gone - the carpark now sits back there.

Thanks for sharing!

Bart.

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 78079827@N07
comment._content: Yes  it was the old stationmasters house,I was born there 1945 nov and we left there to move to Palmerstown in Dublin,I remember all the old Signal men who worked there,My Father worked in the old ticket office now demolished for a period but they stopped using it as a passenger station sometime previous he was transferred to Kingsbridge in Dublin ,we lived at the house till 1960,our family lost two kids in that house and so did the previous family way before us,It went on fire due to sparks from a steam engine getting under the roof slates sometime in the 1950 ties,was origionally for two families way back but we were the only ones living there in the fifties,my father origionally was at the seapoint station before moving to Maynooth...ray Sullivan,Sydney,Australia

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/78079827@N07] Thank you so much, Ray! What fantastic information from the other side of the world.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
